finalPattern.pattern_name: First-person confessional opener plus a blunt, negative verdict about a broadly relevant target (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Sorry‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúThis New Artist Completely Sucks‚Äù) materially lifts TPS by sparking controversy-based curiosity and widening reach beyond core music-theory viewers.

evidence.title: I'm Sorry...This New Artist Completely Sucks
evidence.excerpt: Confessional + blunt verdict + withheld subject; 3.2x above assumed baseline TPS.

evidence.title: I Hate To Say It...Pop Music Is Broken
evidence.excerpt: Apology lead-in with broad negative judgment on 'pop music'.

evidence.excerpt: Self-reversal + decisive negative verdict to drive curiosity.

evidence.excerpt: Confessional apology + blunt negative; broad pop-rock audience.

evidence.excerpt: Confessional + blunt verdict on a widely-seen subject.

data.statement: Titles that combine a first‚Äëperson confessional opener plus a blunt, negative verdict about a broadly relevant target (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Sorry‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚ÄúThis New Artist Completely Sucks‚Äù) drive 3x+ TPS on Rick Beato‚Äôs channel by creating controversy‚Äëbased curiosity and expanding reach beyond core music‚Äëtheory viewers.
data.reasoning: Rick Beato‚Äôs baseline is educational/analytical; when he shifts to a contrarian critique with strong negative valence and a confessional hook, it likely generates higher emotional arousal (anger/curiosity), more comments, and higher CTR from ambiguous targeting (‚Äúnew artist‚Äù) that appeals to a wider audience than niche theory content. The ellipsis + apology frames a narrative (why he feels compelled to say this) and the blunt verdict (‚Äúcompletely sucks‚Äù) promises decisive judgment, reducing cognitive cost to click. The vagueness of ‚Äúnew artist‚Äù withholds the subject, maximizing curiosity. This combination is replicable (title formula, tone, framing) and should correlate with above‚Äëbaseline TPS within his catalog and across similar creator niches.
